description.narrative:
Insatsen avser ett fortsatt stöd om 300msek till FNs trustfond för Somalia "UN Multi-Partnership Trust Fund" (MPTF) under 2017-2019.
MPTF är den främsta finansieringsmekanismen för FN för att stödja genomförandet av prioriteringar som i Somalias nationella utvecklingsplan (NDP).
Somalia är bland de fattigaste länderna i världen och på grund av instabilitet är säkerhetsutmaningar också en av de mest komplicerade miljöerna för utvecklingssamarbete. Landet präglas av ojämställdhet och ojämlikhet. Två årtionden av inbördeskrig och återkommande humanitära kriser, inkl. hungersnöd, har hållit landets befolkning i fattigdom och utsatthet. 2,3 miljoner människor har osäker livsmedelsförsörjning och över en miljon är internflyktingar. Av en befolkning på ca 12 miljoner människor uppskattas till 73 procent vara fattiga och 43 procent leva i extrem fattigdom. En av sju barn dör före sin första födelsedag; en av arton kvinnor dör i förlossningen; och endast en av tre personer har tillgång till säkert dricksvatten. Brist på sysselsättningsmöjligheter lämnar många unga somalier med få framtidsutsikter. Över 70% av Somalias befolkning är under trettio år och arbetslösheten för ungdomar i Somalia är 67 procent, en av de högsta i världen. Kvinnor är strukturerat diskriminerade. Könsrelaterat våld är extremt utbrett. Somalia har den högsta förekomsten av kvinnlig könsstympning i världen. Kvinnor saknar tillgång till rättvisa som kan skydda sina intressen. Bristen på ett formellt och effektivt rättssystem i de flesta delar av landet har lett till omfattande straffrihet. 2016 var Somalia rankat som det mest korrupta landet i världen enligt Transparency Tnternational.
MPTFen etablerades 2015 med Sverige som en av de första givarna att bidra till den nya fonden. Fondens hanterar idag totalt 187 miljoner USD. Det svenska bidraget är det tredje största till fonden. Under perioden 2015-2017 har Sverige stött följande FN program: Icke öronmärkt finansiering för program inom Peace Building Goal (PSG) 1 (val, konstitution, parlament och federalisering), icke-öromärkt finansiering för PSG 4 (Charcoal); öronmärkt finansiering av rättsstatsprogrammet (Rule of Law), öronmärkt finansiering av Ungdomsarbetslöshetprogrammet öronmärkt finansiering av förvaltningsstöd. Dessutom har icke öronmärkt finansiering bidragit till stöd för ”use of country systems” (National Window). Slutligen har även programmet för lokal styrning lyfts in under fonden under perioden.
FN: s MPTF-mekanism är nu fullt fungerande, med engagemang från bidragande givare. Somalia har tagit fram en ny nationell utvecklingsplan (National Development Plan/NDP). MPTF strukturen är den främsta finansierings mekanismen för FNs stöd till regeringen att implementera NDP. En säkerhetspakt har levererats efter Londonkonferensen i maj 2017, vilken lägger ner färdplanen för att säkerställa genomförandet av på federal och regional nivå. Sveriges främsta bidrag till Somalias NDP är således följande bidrag till MPTFen.
Sida föreslår att Sveriges bidrag öronmärks kring följande tematiska områden och projekt och program som beslutas inom ramen för dessa kluster: 1. Inkluderande politik och federalisering 2. Mänskliga rättigheter, fred och säkerhet 3. Ekonomisk utveckling 4. Sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter
Därtill avses ca 15 % öronmärkas till det så kallade "Enablers programme" som innefattar stöd till FNs riskhandteringsenhet, avdelning för säkerhet och trygghet samt Resident Coordinator's Office (RCO) vilket bedömds vara avgörande för all tyd av genomförande på plats i Somalia. MPTFen utgör inte enbart en finansieringsmekanism, utan även en möjlighet för givarkoordinering i bredare bemärkelse. De största givarna som EU, UK, USA, NO, DE, och DK finns fortfarande representerade.
MPTF ett viktigt och helt centralt instrument för det internationella givarsamfundet och den somaliska regeringen i deras samarbete för att förverkliga de övergripande målen om fred och utveckling i Somalia. Slutsatsen är att UNSF och MPTF kommer att harmonisera de betydande resurser som kanaliseras inom FN i Somalia och därmed leda till ett effektivare internationellt stöd till Somalia. Trots många och allvarliga risker, är det sannolikt att uppsatta mål kommer att nås till en rimlig grad om FN, deltagande givare och somaliska aktörer samarbetar för att minska dessa risker. Sverige och andra givare kommer att spela en viktig roll i detta avseende. MPTF är ett centralt instrument för att operationalisera Somalias utvecklingsplan i en tid då utsikterna för verklig fred är bättre än på årtionden, samt för att uppnå viktiga resultat i den svenska resultatstrategin.
Avtalsutkastet följer den mellan UNDP och Sida överenskomna mallen för den nu aktuella formen av samarbetsform. Insatshanteringsregelns krav för avtal är således uppfyllda.

The aim of the intervention is to provide financing for the UN Multi-Partner Trust Fund (MPTF) in Somalia in order to enable the implementation of the goals set out in the Integrated Strategic Framework (ISF), which is an operationalization of priorities and objectives outlined in the Somali Compact.

The overall vision of the ISF, in accordance with the Compact, is to support the Somali process of establishing a sovereign, secure, democratic, united and federal Somalia at peace with itself and the world, and for the benefit of its people.Strategic Objectives:1. Inclusive Politics: Achieve a stable and peaceful federal Somalia through inclusive political processes.2. Security: Establish unified, capable, accountable and rights based Somali federal security institutions providing basic safety and security for its citizens.3. Justice: Establish independent and accountable justice institutions capable of addressing the justice needs of the people of Somalia by delivering justice for all.4. Economic Foundations: Revitalise and expand the Somali economy with a focus on livelihood enhancement, employment generation, and broad-based inclusive growth.5. Revenue and Services: Increase the delivery of equitable, affordable, and sustainable services that promote national peace and reconciliation amongst Somalia’s regions and citizens and enhance transparent and accountable revenue generation and equitable distribution and sharing of public resources.The operationalization of these goals through the UNMPTF is underway and 6 pipeline programmes have been approved in order to ensure funding and start up of delivery of key priority objectives through the mechanism. The funding priorities and initial pipeline for these objectives are (i) Support to Federalism, State Formation, Reconciliation & Dispute Resolution; (ii) Constitutional Review and Implementation Support and (iii) Electoral Assistance; (iv) Strengthening Rule of Law; (v) Youth Employment; (vi) Institutional Capacity Development (cross cutting). In addition Sweden's support to the UN Joint Programme on Local Governance and Service Delivery which is currently in its second phase (JPLG II) will be channelled through the MPTF The aim to align this support to the Compact and funding arrangements of the SDRF. The follow up of the support to the MPTF will be undertaken at two levels: (i) at fund level of the performance of the fund itself, for which the UN has developed performance indicators, and (ii) the actual programmes that the fund is financing. The first will be followed up in several forums within the aid architecture as well as within the specific Risk Management Group (RMG) set up to monitor the implementation of the Risk Management Strategy. The RMG is made up of the two fund administrators (UN and WB) and donor representatives and where Sweden is one of the representatives in the group. The latter will be followed up in the respective project boards set up to follow up on the implementation of the different programmes. See below.Due to the urgency of funding for the initial pipeline programmes and upon request from the UN, contributing donors indicated available funding for the programmes to be approved. Sweden will during this initial phase 2015-2017 earmark its contribution to the UNMPTF for PSG1, PSG4, Youth Employment, Rule of Law, Capacity building and UN Enabling services. For 2017 Sweden will leave limited funding un earmarked in accordance with the ambition to support the full Partnership of the New Deal.The above targeted areas will also be the focus for Sweden's follow up in terms of results frameworks and Sweden will actively particpate in the project boards set up for these programmes. It is also anticipated that additional joint UN programmes will be integrated into the UNMPTF structure, since the aim of the UN is to run a single fund with most UN programmes coordinated and financed through the fund. The above mentioned JPLG is the first of these programmes to migrate into the fund structure. In addition to the objectives of the pipeline programmes this enagement also strengthens the harmonization of One UN delivery mechanims as well as strengthens the New Deal aid architechture and the Peace and Statebuilding goals (PSG) working group system that includes the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) representation, to review, approve and fund UN Projects. Sweden will therefore also follow up on the performance level indicators developed for the MPTF. This will take place in both project board and Steering Committee levels, as well as in the Risk Management Group set up to monitor the implementation of the Risk Management Strategy developed for the fund.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The MPTF was initially guided by the ISF in accordance with the Somalia Compact. In 2017 the Compact was replaced by a New Partnership Agreement and the finalization of a Somalia National Development Plan. In accordance with this progress, the UN developed its Strategic Framework to reflect the development areas of the NDP. In addition, the UN has also responded to the requirement of the Comprehensive Approach to Security agreed upon in December 2017. The UNMPTF is now in its third year of operation and has grown significantly, with a current portfolio of sixteen Joint Programmes capitalized at over USD 220m and there has been an increase in the number of donor partners channeling development assistance through the Fund. By 2017, the following are the main results achieved by the MPTF: The joint RoL programme financed through the fund provides an excellent example of how the fund has enabled joint committmnet from donors, coordinated UN response and Somalia ownership over design, planning and implementation in one of the main areas of support that also links development obectives with security sector outcomes. The Rule of Law programme, which started before the SDRF structure and the MPTF financing mechanism carried with it into the fund structure an inflated work plan and budget way beyond the actual funding available and the participating agencies worked in in silos. Intense donor coordination, where the three donors (UK, EU and SE) to the programme, jointly insisted on a more consolidated programme around the justice chain. The dialoge between donors, UN and Somali counterparts eventually lead to a renewed RoL structure with clear separate outcome documents for each of the main justice chain programmes (Justice, Police and Corrections,) and a governing chapeau lead and coordinated through the RoL Global Focal Point mechanism. These programmes are part of the UN Rule of Law Framework which defines the UN strategic intervention for the next three years and are designed to support the implementation of the National Development Plan and the Comprehensive Approach to Security (CAS). Focus will be placed on further developing and implementing the police, justice and corrections models and expanding services to the population. A significant progress towards federalization of the justice and corrections sectors in Somalia is the FGS and FMS Ministries of Justice signing of a political agreement outlining a more detailed Justice and Corrections Model. The programs also have clear and operational links to the broader security architecture and projects linked to the Comprehensive Approach to Security, such as DDR, SSR, PCVE, CAAC and Defectors programmes. The UN Human Rights programme also ensures a HR due diligence monitoring mechanism of all programmes. Sweden also provided additional funding for a RoL pilot in Baidoa prison addressing rehabilitation of ex combatants and their potential participation in rehabilitation programmes. The pilot was managed by seconded staff from Swedish Prison and Probation Services. The Corrections project under the RoL programme includes expansion of the pilot based on the lessons learned and is also planning to continue the collaboration with the Swedish Prison and Probation Services in implementation of the expanded initiative. The Joint Programme on Support to Emerging Federal States supported a five-day National Reconciliation Conference which served as an important milestone in formulating Somalia’s reconciliation strategy, marking the shift from a predominantly reactive approach to solve emerging conflicts towards a proactive approach based on a solid strategy for sustained reconciliation. Notable achievements also include the political agreement between Ahlu Sunna Waljama’a and Galmudug State on governance, security and power sharing and the ceasefire agreement and reconciliation process between Puntland and Galmudug States on Galkayo. The Joint Programme on Support to Institutions of Parliament supported the advancement of priority legislation, resulting in approval of seven bills by both the National Federal Parliament and Puntland House of Representatives. Following the electoral process supported by the Joint Programme on Electoral Support, a new Federal Parliament was elected in early 2017, comprising 25 per cent women, a significant increase compared to the 14 per cent in the previous Parliament. The 10th Federal Parliament comprises more than 50 per cent new MPs, and about 18 per cent of the elected MPs are under 35 years old. The Joint Programme on Rule of Law supported the establishment of toll-free hotlines for women and child survivors of abuse and supported the Puntland Human Rights Defenders Office to maintain survivor/victim support hotline desks where 480 reports were received and acted upon in 2017. The Programme also supported the provision of emergency care and psychosocial support to 700 victims of gender-based violence during the year. In response to the drought crises in 2017, the Joint Programme on Youth Employment re-programmed parts of its existing and newly-mobilized resources through implementation of Cash-For-Work activities in creating short-term employment for 1,440 (1,061 women) drought-affected people in Somaliland and South West State. With support of the Joint Programme on Local Governance, local governance laws were developed in a consultative manner and finalized in the majority of states. Local councils were formed in two districtsof South West State with the process well underway in Jubaland. The Decentralization Strategy for the education, health and roads sectors was developed and validated in Somaliland and Puntland. Federal Member States in South West, Jubaland and Galmudug finalized their Strategic Plans (2017–2019) aligned to the National Development Plan with support for the Joint Programme on Institutional Capacity Development. The transition from the New Deal based aid architecture towards the NDP structure of Pillar Working Groups was managed by the Aid Coordination Unit (ACU) and Ministry of Planning, Investment and Economic Development. Midnimo supported the increased capacity of local authorities and government line ministry focal persons as trained Core Facilitation Teams in facilitating participatory visioning, planning and prioritization process to identify basic needs and the means to sustain a living for IDPs, returnees and host communities. This effort led to identification and prioritization of community-based projects in the form of Community Action Plans in Kismayo and Baidoa. Significant progress has been made in government led infrastructure projects under the Pilot Project to Strengthen National Service Delivery (National Window). With the success of the initial phases of the project and in the spirit of strengthening government systems, the UN is planning to channel additionalfinances through the government treasury to finance public infrastructure. Under the Joint Programme on Enablers, the Office of the UN Resident Coordinator (RCO) continuedsupport to Somalia’s aid architecture, including support to development of the New Partnership for Somalia and its Mutual Accountability Framework, as well as support to the Somalia Partnership Forum in December. In Somaliland, the RCO coordinated UN agencies support for the development of Somaliland’s new development plan. The RCO also led the finalization of the new UN Strategic Framework (UNSF) which was signed by government on 5 December 2017.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
